citation.article-title: Heliothrix oregonensis, gen. nov., sp. nov., a phototrophic filamentous gliding bacterium containing bacteriochlorophyll a.

p.s: Description of Heliothrix gen. nov.
Heliothrix (helios-Gk, m: sun; thrix-Gk, fem:hair)
Morphology.
Filaments of indefinite length, unbranched, undifferentiated with gliding motility, and no flagella.
Filaments clearly septate.
Thin sheath may or may not be present.
Cells much longer than broad (ca. 10 μm in length and ca. 1.5 μm in diameter).
Cell division by fission in one plane.
No resting cells or gas vacuoles known.
Gram-negative.
Refractile inclusions primarily poly-β-hydroxybutyric acid (PHB).
No intracytoplasmic membranes.
No chlorosomes.
Pigmentation and physiology.
Masses of filaments bright orange in color.
Contains bacteriochlorophyll a as only chlorophyll.
Carotenoids include γ-carotene glucosides and oxygenated derivatives of γ-carotene. β- and γ-carotene and oxygenated derivatives of β-carotene present only in trace amounts if at all.
Photoheterotrophic and aerotolerant.
Moderately thermophilic (optimum photosynthetic activity between 45 and 55 °C).
Source.
Mats in alkaline hot springs.
Warm Springs Indian Reservation, Warm Springs, Oregon.
Type strain.
Culture IS/F-1 is designated as holotype.
It is a co-culture with Isosphaera pallida.
The co-culture is deposited in the culture collection of Thermophilic Microorganisms, Department of Biology, University of Oregon
